content.webTitle: Broadchurch recap: series three, episode three – only 98 red herrings this week. Do keep up!

fields.headline: Broadchurch recap: series three, episode three – only 98 red herrings this week. Do keep up!
fields.bodyText: Catch up on the episode two recap here Dear me, this is not a good advert for coastal living, or 50th birthday parties, or male friends of any kind. “How many men were at your party?” “Too many.” Quite. The net widened. The plot thickened. And Taxi Man appeared to incriminate himself on multiple levels – while being way too obvious a suspect at this stage. We wouldn’t expect things to be clarified to any major degree by this point, so it’s fair to say that the story moved at the pace it should tonight without anything major happening. Gripping is not the word, but it was compelling enough. Humour was jettisoned (apart from a fleeting Scotch egg moment) for suspense. The list of suspects grew to ridiculous proportions and Trish continued to receive anonymous communications which bloomed creepily from text messages to flowers. A few things grated. Why no more investigations into what Trish did in the time between the rape and reporting it? Have they forgotten about this? Why is no one asking why Cath has so few women friends? Why has no one noticed that most of the suspects have beards and that this might jog Trish’s memory? (I know, I know. I am wasted in this job.) Trish’s beachside stroll with Cath was the most revelatory moment here. She genuinely can’t remember who her attacker is. (Previously, I felt this was ambiguous.) And the “swinging” idea seems to have collapsed too, as the musician and the man from the farm shop would have mentioned those goings on. We still don’t know who Trish is protecting, though. Who was at her house on the Saturday morning? (My money is on Ed Burnett.) And how much longer can she hold out against Miller and Hardy? “You know how it feels to be violated and feel like it’s your fault?” “I don’t know how that feels. No.” It feels like deja vu that Miller’s porn-loving son and the Latimers constitute the main sub-plots. The two stories reached their inevitable crossover as Trish identified Beth thanks to the wonders of Google. Plus, there’s another crossover with Miller’s son being best friends with Taxi Man’s stepson. (Do keep up.) How many red herrings will pile up before we, the audience, feel too manipulated? Let’s wait and see. I have a feeling the discrepancies in Taxi Man’s stories will be ironed out next week and he will turn out to be guilty of some other crime. “Why are you lying to us, Lucas? We called all these people and you didn’t take any of them.” The coldness of “Are you married, Lucas?” was magical. The scene with his wife was a bit strange, though. Lucas/Clive does not seem the type to have a medical degree. And his wife suggested he hasn’t given up his ambitions? From what we have seen, I doubt he could write a prescription. I worried about some of the police procedure too. Can it be productive to track condom purchases? Would Hardy be so rude to Harford when they’re all working overtime? Would Miller really consider accepting Deli Man’s offer of free food? Too many questions. We had better start getting a hint of some answers next week. Miller v Hardy: the score so far Miller, Scotch egg in her gob, won this episode hands down. She’s in control of everything (except for her son’s phone). Hardy, meanwhile, is starting to lose it. “Why did you come back here?” Ah, so now we come to it. “The place I thought was home wasn’t any more.” This should be an important emerging theme. What has Hardy got to prove? “I know you’re tired. I know you want a result. But you’ve got to go easier.” “I’m scared he’s going to do it again. That’s why I’m pushing.” “Daisy’s dad” is under pressure. Now we need to see him crack to move things forward ... Miller 28, Hardy 0. Not the usual suspects “It feels like the more we interview, the more we rule in.” Tell us about it, Miller! There really can be no man left in Christendom, let alone Broadchurch, who is not a suspect. There’s enough to fill an actual entire wall. Thanks, Harford. The two main suspects (the ex-husband and Cath’s husband Jim) came face-to-face at Atwood’s Autos. “I think I might be in the shit ... I made it all up ... You can tell them what I’m like when I drink tequila ... My wife has been raped and I don’t know where I was.” Blimey. Does the ex-husband’s standing-outside-the-house phone call let him off the hook? He surely can’t be the one who sent the text message? And yet he also has secrets on his computer? He appeared to be exonerated for a moment and then suddenly wasn’t. I predict that he is dodgy but for other reasons entirely. Jim Atwood’s story seemed to stack up with Ed Burnett’s account of their fight. “I hope someone’s said to you that she wouldn’t do anything to provoke this. She is not that sort of woman.” Then Cath’s comment seemed to indicate that Ed was lying about when he left – and she suspects her husband of lying too. “Did I rape one of our best friends? I really need to answer that?” And then came more suspects, as if we needed them. Deli Man (“from the farm shop”) and his walk around the lake. The old buffer from the stately home talking about the old waterfall under the tree. And the musician as well, except he immediately incriminated Deli Man, Suspect No 487. “That bloke from the farm shop looked like he wanted to kill someone.” How exhausting. Life lesson Don’t say you’ve driven people home when you didn’t because they will be able to tell the police that you didn’t. It’s fairly basic. Trademark Wessex words of wisdom “We are probably going to retrieve his DNA from your bedsheets anyway.” Hardy appears to have ditched the whole be-sensitive-to-the-rape-victim thing. “Are you really going to drink that disgusting stewed tea?” Hardy and his microwaved tea. Eugh. No wonder he is in such a foul mood. “He doesn’t like me, does he?” “It’s not about you.” Don’t worry, Harford. He doesn’t like anyone. “I’m sleeping in my daughter’s box room while she works herself to death. It’s the retirement I always dreamed of.” More from Miller’s dad please.
